subject: RE: [junit] Future of testing tools
msgSnippet: Hi Kent, Actually I love test driven development and double checking, because it leads me to simplify my methods to the point where I feel I have a solid grasp
messageBody:
Hi Kent,

Actually I love test driven development and double
checking, because it leads me to simplify my methods
to the point where I feel I have a solid grasp on
what's going on.

However I want everything 100% tested. A lot of
eyebrowes go up when I say that.

"OK - His cheeze is off the cracker", type whispering.

I do have a very specific idea in mind for this
though.

In summarized form it would be something like this:

Automatically generate datasets
testing all the corner cases and edge cases and let
the developer evaluate the method based on the
input parameters and corresponding results.

In example form it's something like this:

Suppose I have a function

public int add(int x, int y)....

What would we test?

Suppose it's a AMD 64 platform, and the test
generator is aware that the the biggest and smallest
int's values for the int datatype are

dIntMax and dIntMin.

We could test and see what happens when:

x + y > dIntMax

x + y < dIntMax (Valid parameters)

x + y = dIntMax (Valid parameters)

The same for the negative.

This helps the developer validate the method, by
passing the generated input parameters and evaluating
the result.

Edge conditions would look at what happens at the
edges of decisions.

For instance x < 10

would be tested by

x = 9

x = 11

when x is an int...

And so on...

Now in this example if the method body says

x*y

the generated tests will be right, per the definition
of the method body, but wrong with respect to what the
developer or designer intended the method to do.

However the developer will be able to run the method
through the automatically generated datasets and
notice that 3*3 != 6.

The tool would tell the developer that the 3*3 test
corresponds to valid values for the input parameters.

So a method body interpreter/branch enumerator must be
developed that can enumerate the method body, generate
all the edge and corner case datasets, and then some
nice tooling on top for running datasets and
interpreting results.

Looking at the number of edge and corner cases per
method is also a good indicator of whether the method
needs to be simplified.

I think something like this would be a nice complement
to something like PMD, which Yoakim pointed out.

We keep the baby, and still flush the tub :-)

Cheers,
- Ole






--- Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:

> Dear Ole,
>
> I understand your suggestion to be about efficiency.
> To the degree that
> there is redundancy between the code and the tests,
> it feels like a waste of
> time, and you'd like to eliminate that waste.
>
> One of the principles involved in testing is double
> checking--say something
> in two different ways and if they match, you have a
> good chance you are
> saying what you intend to say. The philosophical
> problem I have with
> generating code from tests, or test from code, or
> tests and code from some
> other notation, is that it ignores double checking.
> The baby of
> double-checking goes out with the bathwater of
> redundancy.
>
> I like the JUnitFactory tests because they give me
> an independent
> perspective on my code. Manually inspecting
> generated tests gives me a
> measure of double checking. "Really?!?
> factorial(100) == 0???"
>
> Programming language design seemed for many years to
> be the quest for a
> notation so clear that programmers couldn't make
> mistakes. The
> small-but-growing popularity of developer testing
> seems to me to be evidence
> that double checking is a more fruitful strategy for
> achieving reliable
> software.
>
> All of that said, I agree with the desire for less
> redundant test notations.
> @Theory, for example, seems to promise more
> confidence/line of test code.
>
> Regards,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
>

> Hi Kent,
>
> We had a pretty good discussion around this
> on this thread:
>
> http://www.nabble.
>
<http://www.nabble.com/100---Method-Testing-and-Generating-Unit-Tests-tf2902
> 785.html>
>
com/100---Method-Testing-and-Generating-Unit-Tests-tf2902785.html
>
> I think we could summarize it to having a design
> tool
> that helps design the architecture of the system,
> perhaps narrowed by concern area and architectural
> layer (Presentation, application, business,
> integration ,data) and then generates tests that
> enumerate all the corner and edge cases, helping the
> designer / developer validate the system.
>
> Personally I would like to see it combined with
> something like this:
>
> http://www.eclipse.
>
<http://www.eclipse.org/articles/Article-EMF-Codegen-with-OCL/article.html>
>
org/articles/Article-EMF-Codegen-with-OCL/article.html
>
> Something that generates both the application code
> and
> the corresponding test cases. Then makes it as
> simple
> as possible for the users / solution recipients to
> validate the system.
>
> I'm going to summarize the thread in a little apache
> licensed eclipse documentation plugin just
> elaborating
> on the enumeration methodology, etc. discussed in
> the
> thread. I'll post back when it's done.
>
> BTW - Thanks a gazillion (To Eric as as well) for
> writing "Contributing to Eclipse" and JUnit. I think
> calling it "Briliant work" would be an
> understatement.
>
> Cheers,
> - Ole
>
> --- Kent Beck <kentb@earthlink.
> <mailto:kentb%40earthlink.net> net> wrote:
>
> > All,
> >
> >
> >
> > At the Agile Open Northwest conference I held an
> > open space session on the
> > future of testing tools. I expected to talk a
> little
> > about Theories and
> > assertThat, but we ended up having a wide-ranging
> > discussion about a variety
> > of topics. I mind-mapped the result and put in on
> > the conference wiki:
> >
> >
> http://www.agileope
>
<http://www.agileopennorthwest.com/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?FutureOfUnitTesting>
> nnorthwest.com/cgi-bin/wiki.pl?FutureOfUnitTesting
> >
> >
> >
> > The most surprising result to me was the interest
> in
> > language features for
> > testing-what would a language look like that
> > included double-checking as a
> > first-class concept? I was also surprised at how
> > much commonality there was
> > between the unit and functional testing "vendors",
> > that reporting is a big
> > issue for everyone.
> >
> >
> >
> > One thing missing from the discussion was much
> talk
> > about the hopes and
> > dreams of users, so I thought I would open up the
> > question here. What is it
> > you wish your testing tool would do for you that
> it
> > doesn't?
> >
> >
> >
> > Cheers,
> >
> >
> >
> > Kent Beck
